(1) A permit is subject to such conditions as are specified in the permit or as are imposed under subsection (2).
(2) The Minister may, in accordance with the regulations:
(a) vary or revoke a condition of a permit; or
(b) impose further conditions of a permit.
The holder of a permit is guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction by a fine not exceeding 300 penalty units if:
(a) he or she does, or fails to do, an act or thing; and
(b) doing, or failing to do, the act or thing results in a contravention of a condition of the permit.

(1) Subject to subsection (2), the holder of a permit may give to a person written authority to do for or on behalf of the holder any act authorised by the permit. The authority may be given generally or as otherwise provided by the instrument of authority.
(2) The holder of a permit must not give an authority unless:
(a) the permit contains a condition permitting the holder to do so; and
(b) the authority is given in accordance with any requirements set out in the condition.

(3) A permit is, for the purposes of this Act, taken to authorise the doing of a particular act by a person if the doing of that act by the person is authorised by an authority given by the holder of the permit.
(4) The giving of an authority does not prevent the doing of any act by the holder of the permit.
(5) Except as provided in this section, a permit does not authorise the doing of any act by a person for or on behalf of the holder of the permit.
(6) A person who gives an authority must give to the Minister written notice of it within 14 days after giving the authority.
On the application, in accordance with the regulations, of the holder of a permit, the Minister may, in accordance with the regulations, transfer the permit to another person.
The Minister may, in accordance with the regulations:
(a) suspend a permit for a specified period; or
(b) cancel a permit.
Such fees as are prescribed (if any) are payable in respect of the following:
(a) the grant or the transfer of a permit;
(b) the variation or revocation of a condition of a permit;
(c) the imposition of a further condition of a permit.

The reason for our now having to move 248 amendments is that the government has completely failed the House; it has failed to give proper consideration to this environment legislation. Indeed, a great deal of its consideration of this legislation has been done in secret in a deal with the Democrats, who refused to invite the Australian Conservation Foundation—one of this nation's premier conservation bodies—to participate in the drafting process of that legislation. As a result, this legislation is so poor that we need 248 amendments. The Australian Democrats—those fairies at the bottom of the garden turned chainsaw wielding hobgoblins—failed to consult with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the other relevant environment bodies in the drafting of this bill and, as a result, it is fundamentally flawed.

It was not just the Australian Conservation Foundation with whom they failed to consult. We have in our possession a letter from a number of senior environmental experts: Professor Rob Fowler from the Australian Centre for Environmental Law; Professor Neil Gunningham also from the Australian Centre for Environmental Law; Associate Professor Donna Craig from the Law Division of the University of Sydney; David Hayes, Senior Lecturer in Law at James Cook University; Professor for Environmental Law from the Australian Centre for Environmental Law, Ben Boare; and Jan Macdonald, Associate Professor of Law at Bond University, together with Brian Hayes QC. Those senior environmental lawyers point out that the legislation before the House contains a number of substantial flaws.

talk.start.para: —It's not green; it's gangrene.

—Indeed, gangrene. First, that it has a limited range of matters which may trigger Commonwealth involvement in environmental impact assessment; secondly, that, even where that limited range of matters arise, they can be exempted through the execution of bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and the states; and, thirdly, that amendments to the bill have not eliminated this possibility but rather have simply provided an extra layer, an extra procedural hoop to the already complex process for producing bilateral agreements.

speech.para: Those important concerns are added to by the fact that this bill should have received adequate parliamentary consideration and, in the words of the authors, `should not have been pushed through for political expediency as this process will not lead to good law'. Those legal experts are absolutely right. For those reasons, we have moved our 248 amendments.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to stand and speak in support of this landmark legislation, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1999 and the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1999 . This legislation represents the Howard coalition government's commitment to the better protection of Australia's unique environment and splendid biodiversity through proper management standards and transparent assessment processes. In historical terms, the earliest significant environmental legislation by the Commonwealth government was the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, which was enacted by the Whitlam government and represented a nascent stirring of awareness of the fragility and value of the natural environment of Australia.

speech.para: This legislation represents extensive consultation between the Commonwealth, the states, industry representatives, community groups and indigenous communities. It also reflects the government's determined and comprehensive effort to define environment responsibilities at Commonwealth level. This enactment is the most fundamental reform of Commonwealth environmental statutes for nearly 25 years. This is comprehensive reform because it also reflects a maturity in Commonwealth-state relations whereby areas of respective responsibility in environment assessment processes are defined. This bill will also provide for the first time an important national leverage to ensure the highest standards of environmental accreditation processes across the country.

Since the coalition government was elected in 1996, the federal government has enjoyed a sound cooperative working relationship with state governments. Both federal and state governments have sought to identify better means of delivering efficient and effective environmental management for Australia as a whole, which will effectively balance the needs of the environment with the needs of industry.

In 1997, the Council of Australian Governments reached an agreement by which the Commonwealth's role in environmental management would be defined by matters of national environmental significance. COAG also agreed that part of the reform process should include an innovative relationship between state and Commonwealth laws through an effective mechanism of accreditation by the Commonwealth of state assessment and approval processes. This bill puts the COAG agreement into effect.

The Commonwealth's role is confined to those areas identified as being of national environmental significance. These areas are the Commonwealth marine area, world heritage properties, Ramsar wetlands of international importance, nationally threatened species and ecological communities, internationally protected migratory species, and nuclear actions by the Commonwealth or Commonwealth agencies. As a major part of the reform process, this legislation will also replace five existing statutes on environment and conservation. These are the Environment Protection (Impact of proposals) Act 1974, the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Whale Protection Act 1980 and the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. These new bills reflect the changing attitudes and rapid advances in environmental and biodiversity management which aim to employ world's best practice in line with contemporary community expectations.

One of the main aims of the legislation is to promote ecologically sustainable development and to conserve our precious biodiversity. The structure of the main bill will allow the Commonwealth to respond to emerging environment concerns and environ mental planning and assessment practice. An important aspect of the challenge of this reform bill is to balance the needs of industry and development with the needs of the conservation of the environment. This reform bill seeks to establish that balance.

Benefits for Australian industry will include statutory time frames in which decisions must be made. This in turn will also provide a considerable measure of certainty to proponents, which has not always been available under the existing act. The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill relies on direct, specifically defined environmental criteria.

The proponents of a development will know from the outset whether or not a project or an activity will trigger Commonwealth involvement. Should the proponent be in any doubt as to whether this legislation is applicable, they may apply to the minister and the minister must make a binding decision within 20 days on whether or not the legislation is triggered. It is important for industry to note that, once the minister has given this decision, the proponent may rely on this decision with certainty. There are strict limitations on the possibility for this decision to be reconsidered, thus minimising the opportunity for any late intervention by the Commonwealth. This is an important aspect of this bill which ensures greater certainty and efficiency for industry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have just heard another coalition speaker in this debate tell us what a landmark piece of legislation this is. If it is such a landmark piece of legislation, why the completely shameful haste in getting it through the Senate before 30 June and then returning it to this House and gagging the debate so quickly? Why wouldn't you put the bill out for consultation with the environment groups in its radically amended form and get some feedback? I will tell you what the answer to that is: despite all the claims of `landmark', everybody participating in this debate knows this is about rolling back Commonwealth responsibility and rolling back environmental standards. If you put it out there in the com munity, if you give it to the environment groups, that is what they are going to tell you.

speech.para: It is a very sensitive issue in my electorate, because we have Ramsar wetlands, we have the petrochemical industry making some of the most noxious and dangerous substances on earth—that is, if they are not properly dealt with—and we had the Kennett government proposal for a toxic dump in Werribee. 15,000 members of my electorate went out on a winter night—which was as cold as it can be in Canberra—to the Werribee racecourse to protest against that decision. Because I think it is very important to the final position that the Democrats have taken in this debate, let me take you to what the Democrats said to the 15,000 people who were at the Werribee racecourse protesting about the Werribee toxic dump when they were looking for votes in the run-up to the last federal election.

Did the Democrats come out to Werribee and say during that campaign, `Once we are in parliament, we will do a dirty deal with the coalition to ensure that the Commonwealth government washes its hands of protecting Ramsar wetlands and hands the whole thing—the whole issue it cannot be bothered with—back to the states'? No, they did not come out to Werribee and say that; in fact, the Democrats came out to Werribee and said quite the opposite. Democrat Senator Lyn Allison said:
The Howard government needs to get moving with the states on establishing national, enforceable guidelines for storing toxic waste.

Not content with that, she went on to give the following Democrat commitment to the people of my electorates: residents should have the right of veto against projects like the toxic dump via a residential ballot and activated by a petition of 1,000 or more. That was the commitment she made to the electors in Lalor. One notes that the Democrats are very big on petitions: big on having rules about them, but not so good on acting on them when they get them—otherwise they would be in the middle of a leadership ballot. They are pretty big on making promises to constituents when they are in the run-up to a federal election. They came out to Werribee in the electorate of Lalor and said to people who had been campaigning for two years, `This is what we will do if we are returned to the federal parliament.'

They also promised to introduce a bill in the Senate to stop the Werribee toxic dump. Fortunately, no-one had to rely on the Democrats to deliver. If we had had to rely on the Democrats to deliver, we would see the Werribee toxic dump already in the construction stage. Instead of relying on the Democrats to deliver, the people of Werribee kept campaigning. Ultimately it was not a political party—not the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Democrats—that came to their rescue. Because the people of Werribee campaigned so hard, ultimately CSR, the project developer that wanted to make money out of putting toxic waste in Werribee, decided that it had had enough and that it would not proceed with the project.

It is important to recognise that, despite those commitments from the Democrats, in this legislation they have enabled the states and the Commonwealth to now go through a process where, through a bilateral agreement, in future the Commonwealth could say to Victoria—and states with track records of environmental vandalism like Victoria—`Here, you have the responsibility for the Ramsar wetlands. Here, you have the responsibility for the environmental impacts of a toxic dump,' and just let it happen. Despite all their brave rhetoric that is where the Democrats have led us to by entering into this agreement with the government—an agreement that they did not need to enter into and did not need to deal with in this time frame. They could have had the decency to come back to the people that they had made grandiose promises to and work them through the issues, if they thought this was the right course. Instead, here we have legislation gagged and the Democrats not abiding by their word. I am sure they will be harshly judged by my electors when it comes to the next election. We know one thing in Werribee—that the coalition does not care about the environment. After all, they are the party that wanted to put a toxic dump on top of us. Today, through this bill, we have proof positive that, despite their campaigning rhetoric, the Democrats are exactly the same. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have heard a lot of nonsense from every one of the speakers from the opposition tonight.

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —In particular, just recently we have heard references to Victoria and its conservation record. It is quite extraordinary. We hear a lot about something like a toxic waste dump and of course that is a very significant issue.

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —But let us look at Victoria's record in terms of its water reform and its vegetation management. It is in fact leading the country.

speech.para: Over the other side of the House there is such a narrow view of what constitutes environmental conservation. Because our environmental legislators are working with interest groups who in fact have supported the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1999 , they have been denigrated. The member for Wills referred to the `teenage behaviour and silliness' of those who were working with us. With the Democrats' support, we put through some very significant amendments to this bill in the Senate. It is not a very smart move to denigrate those who understand that we do not have forever to work out better ways to deal with the environment through legislative reform.
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This legislation had a very long period of gestation.

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for the Northern Territory.
—Order! The member for the Northern Territory is warned.
—Might I ask why?

—I allowed the member for the Northern Territory to interject, which I ought not to have done. He persisted and then I called him. When I called him he said, `Yes, what do you want?' No response to the chair is ever acceptable and for that reason he is warned.

—Both the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1999 and this bill, but in particular the significant bill in front of us, were developed after a long period of discussion and gestation. We have already heard about the relationship with COAG. This legislation revision was foreshadowed in 1996, when the environmental election policy statement, `Saving our natural heritage', and the `Investing in our natural heritage' budget statement quite clearly identified the need for major legislative reform of environmental law. We also have had public consultation, which went on for some time. The Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, released a public consultation paper on 23 February 1998 for one month of public consultation. That picked up on the COAG review. Some of you might dismiss the COAG review, but it is a most significant body comprising all states and territories, the Commonwealth and local government together deciding on what is best for the nation.

speech.para: It is amazing that you tend to denigrate the states' involvement in the future sharing of environmental consideration and enactment of proper due process and laws in this country. Since we are about to celebrate 100 years of Federation, it is a little sad that you still seem to think that you do not need to work in cooperation on issues like biodiversity protection. The realities are that you need to work not only with the states but with local government, with stakeholders and with non-government organisations. This Commonwealth government understands only too well that the complexity of the issues that now face us—with our environmental degradation, loss of biodiversity, inappropriate vegetation management and, in some cases, inappropriate introduction of animals which have disturbed our biodiversity—requires, on every front, cooperation between the states and Commonwealth. The member for Dunkley made the point that it is not just coalition governments in the states. There are also some three Labor held states in this period of our federation and we are working just as closely with them. It is to denigrate your own side of politics to say that the states cannot be trusted, and it is not right to deride what they consider a most significant set of amendments to legislation, legislation which has been crying out to be improved for a very long time.

Let me say, too, and I will address it later on, that this legislation has been developed in consultation with the indigenous leadership of this country and they, too, are welcoming it as a major landmark—a step forward to understanding how we must address 200 years of, in many cases, inappropriate actions that have left our natural resources depleted and degraded.

talk.start.para: —I hope that, in summing up, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage was not regarding my contribution as insignificant, but I doubt that she was. I want to make some general comments on the thrust of the environment bills, concerned as I am for our national environmental program post-Telstra, funded, as much of it is, from the Natural Heritage Trust. I also find it appalling that this so-called landmark legislation is again being rammed through the House—another example of executive contempt for representative democracy.

speech.para: I remember so well speaking in the House on the bill providing for the sale of the first third of Telstra and pointing out how the Murray-Darling 2001 Program was in fact a 2101 project, so vast are the environmental problems we are confronted with. The former member for Barker, once the shadow minister for the environment, backed up my assessment immediately after that speech. We have heard again in recent days how desperate is the salination problem, particularly in Western Australia, and notably throughout the western parts of New South Wales. In his second reading speech, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage said the Howard government is dealing with issues such as land degradation and the retention of remnant bushland through the Natural Heritage Trust. As I said in the Telstra speech, once we have sold the silverware we can only make the money go so far, and the land degradation problems we face will not be solved by the Natural Heritage Trust. So much for environmental restoration. How about environment protection?

These bills, based on a COAG agreement, seek to ensure the seamless integration of Commonwealth and state laws through what the minister calls a `transparent mechanism for Commonwealth accreditation of state processes'. It is efficient to combine five acts into one. It is efficient to remove the uncertainty surrounding Commonwealth involvement in environmental matters. It appears efficient to provide accreditation of state processes and agreed management plans, assuming these are uniform across all the states. It is important to clarify those areas of pre-eminent national importance such as the Commonwealth marine area. Having worked on the committee of this parliament looking into Australia's fisheries, I must say it is one area requiring constant supervision and research. Similarly, I trust the approval process for actions having an impact on notionally threatened or internationally protected migratory species will include places like the Macquarie Marshes in New South Wales, which are subjected to ongoing and growing pressures from a variety of water users, including wildlife.

I have grave doubts about the ability of state governments and local governments to act in the best national environmental interests, and hence my nervousness about certain aspects of these bills. Queensland, for instance, is accommodating 80 per cent of our land clearance at the moment, and we are tipped to increase by 25 per cent our carbon emissions, not the eight per cent we negotiated at Kyoto. The political pressure on state governments to approve developments, whether on the coast or inland, whether tourism or mining, can and do cloud environmental judgments. Fraser Island, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, the Franklin Dam, Lake Pedder, water management, land clearing and forestry management—all these areas leave one wondering if the states are ready for any new responsibilities. All too often those questioning a development do not have the resources to challenge the contentions of environmental consultants hired to prepare impact studies. There needs to be an independent national environmental impact assessment for projects meeting certain impact criteria. I wonder how we determine, as these bills proscribe, `an activity which does not have a significant impact on one of the matters of national significance'? A mine or a quarry on the headwaters of any stream in the Murray-Darling has the potential to cause an impact of national significance.

On balance, I must accept the work that has gone into these environment bills and the assurances from many sides involved that they will work, or at least work better than the disparate processes we have in place now. But I have no other means of judging, except those comments. I have not had time to study these bills. I have not had time to look at the amendments. The bills have been steamrollered through in the same disgraceful fashion as the so-called Democrats set that rolling gag in motion in the Senate. So much for the term `Democrats' applied to that particular group. I have had insufficient time to get the feedback or study I would like. I would like to support elements of this legislation, but I am ill-prepared to assess these bills in the allotted time. I will therefore be abstaining from recording a vote because I have certainly not had the time to look at the bills in the detail that my constituents demand.

talk.start.para: —Under the current environment legislation, once the Commonwealth government is involved in the assessment process it assesses all the environmental issues involved in the project, including those issues which are really the responsibility and the province of state governments. These bills will permit the Commonwealth to be involved only in the assessment of an activity which relates to those matters specified as `a matter of national environmental significance'. The state governments will be responsible for assessing other environmental issues.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am loath to do it to the member for Hughes, but we are debating the 248 amendments which are before the House. The government did move the gag on the previous bill, and the member for Hughes is referring to the bill.

—Yes, the member for Prospect is right with her point of order. In fact, I was granting some leniency because I understood that there had been some compression of the time for speeches during the second reading stage.

—I am indicating why some leniency was granted. `Theys' and `us' do not exist in the eyes of the Speaker, as the member for Banks should be aware. The member for Hughes will refer to the amendments before the chair.

—Mr Speaker, I have not had the benefit of seeing the amendments that are before the chair—all 300 or 500 of them. I am sorry, but my problem is going to be that I cannot refer to the amendments as I do not have any knowledge of them.

speech.para: Government member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Can I? All right. I have to be honest.
—The member for Hughes will be guided in her participation more by the Speaker than by the whip, I trust. But I will listen closely to what she has to say.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. It behoves me to point out, with regret, that I do understand the comments that were initially made by the member for Lalor in her concern about a toxic waste dump that was going to be imposed upon her electorate. The people of my electorate actually had a nuclear waste dump imposed upon them during the 13 years of the previous Labor government. For the last eight of those 13 years a minister of the Crown actually represented the people of my electorate. I think the people in this country really do have a concern for the environment. The community consultation process that I believe is made available in this current legislation is most important. It is proper and right for the community to have that kind of input.

speech.para: The nuclear waste dump that was allowed to accrue in my electorate during the 13 years of the previous government is of great concern inasmuch as the people were not allowed any input into what the government was about to do and that the government did not have any will to remove the nuclear waste. Of course, in the last three years since we have been in government we have actually made great progress with the ARPANSA legislation and also with looking for a nuclear waste repository of national importance in South Australia.

I do think that, more than anything else, in its consultation with the state governments and with Aboriginal communities, particularly the people in the Northern Territory, on the legislation we are considering today, the government has had a great deal of respect for the knowledge and the renowned affection that the Aboriginal communities have for the land. Under this legislation they will be invited to participate in the committees advising the minister in relation to biodiversity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to respond specifically to the suggestions made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, at the table, about indigenous involvement in the development of these amendments and of the legislation. The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1999 and the amendments will have a significant effect on the legal and social interests of indigenous communities and traditional owners throughout Australia. This legislation was developed with negligible consultation with indigenous communities, even in areas where traditional owners hold freehold title over large areas of land affected by the bills. I name in particular Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and Kakadu National Park, both of which of course are in the Northern Territory.

speech.para: Consequently, in relation to both their general structure and specific provisions, the bills and the amendments fail to appropriately reflect the interests, aspirations and legal rights of indigenous peoples. The bills fail to provide structures for appropriate consultation with indigenous peoples in a range of decision making processes, including bilateral agreements. They may impair or extinguish aspects of title, although I note that these amendments before the House tonight seek to impact upon that by claiming that they will not affect native title rights. They will significantly undermine, however, world respect for joint management practises in Kakadu and Uluru-Kata Tjuta national parks, threatening public access to these parks through traditional owners' possible termination of these leases.

The overarching concerns of indigenous peoples relate to the bills' disregard for the principles of joint management. Joint management is a central part of the contractual arrangements that leases back to the Commonwealth the indigenous people's own land in Kakadu National Park, Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and Wreck Bay. It has been indicated that such contractual arrangements would not have been entered into without the legal guarantee of the principles of joint management. The Kakadu Board of Management has stated that the key aspect of joint management is a process of negotiation and empowerment.

The Uluru-Kata Tjuta Board of Management has stated that, although the current act is not really strong for traditional owners because at the end of the day the minister can direct the board, joint management has worked reasonably well. The reason for this is goodwill and honesty. Given the centrality of these contractual principles, the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council have stated that the lack of negotiation on key aspects of the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1999 is `coercive and pre-emptive of the existing rights of traditional owners'.

I want to refer to an article in the Australian of 25 June 1999 headed `Act of convenience threatens ecology'. What we need to comprehend in this legislation and in the amendments which are before the House is that there has been no adequate consultation with the community. What we have here is an unholy alliance between the Democrats and the government, a marriage of convenience which will not assist environmental protection in this country. I am concerned that we have people in this chamber who actually believe that there has been adequate consultation. I might say that I have had representations from indigenous peoples in the Northern Territory, which is the seat I represent, who have been outspoken about the lack of consultation, lack of involvement and lack of notice taken of them by this government. They have been particularly condemnatory of the way in which the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, has involved himself in these discussions.

This is not a debate about clarifying the responsibilities of each level of government for the protection of the environment; this debate is about the Howard government's determination to revisit history and to remake it. There is no doubt that this day represents a sad culmination of the unholy alliance between the Democrats and the government over the issue of the environment. What we are about today is the determination of the coalition partners and the Democrats to bend over backwards to facilitate this return of the Howard government to the past. This article I referred to makes some cogent points about what this bill will mean. It says in its conclusion:

The end result is likely to be greater uncertainty and heightened conflict across Australia in relation to environmental decisions—precisely what the Act was supposed to avoid. There certainly is little prospect of either the Government or the Democrats being accorded any environmental kudos for having adopted what will prove to be fundamentally flawed legislation.

debate.para: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or request:
Customs and Excise Amendment (Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme) Bill 1999

debateinfo.title: DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration forthwith.
(1) Clause 2, page 2 (lines 14 to 18), omit subparagraph (i), substitute:

(i) Regulation 83 of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, relating to uniform provisions concerning the approval of vehicles with regard to the emission of pollutants according to engine fuel requirements, incorporating all amendments up to and including the 04 Series of Amendments;

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendment be agreed to.

It is a good opportunity at this late hour while we await some further material from the Senate to make some remarks about the value of this diesel grants scheme package to rural and regional Australia. All members would be aware that the 24 per cent of Australians who do not live in urban Australia have been experiencing very real difficulties in recent years. Terms of trade have moved against us very considerably as a number of global factors have come into play, one of which is that population growth has plateaued earlier than people might have expected. Another is that, to an extent that could not have been foreseen in times gone by, we have enormously enhanced our capacity to produce food and fibre. This means that, in a situation where once the world lined up to buy almost anything that we could produce in bulk in this country—food, fibre, the lot—we now find that global markets are highly competitive. Argentina, for example, now every year seeks to place a very considerable amount of wheat on global markets. We never would have anticipated that. India not only is self-sufficient in grains but has a surplus to export. These sorts of factors have led to a situation of very significant deterioration in the terms of trade of the Australian agriculture sector and the attendant rural communities.

A similar pattern has been emerging in relation to commodities—iron ore, coal and the other extractive industries. These factors have led to a situation where we need to do everything we can in this country to contain those areas that have been damaging our terms of trade—where we have some say over them. Mr Speaker, as you will be well aware, the terms of trade are a function of domestic input costs as well as prices received mainly on export markets for a country like ours where the vast bulk of what we produce is exported. Therefore, it makes a great deal of sense to do everything that you can to reduce transport costs. I believe that, for some years in this country, transport costs have been very seriously inflated. They have been very unwisely inflated, in the broader national interest, by the taxes and charges on transport. It is never a sound principle to tax productive inputs where you can avoid it, but the level of taxation inputs in this country—
Consideration interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: —I think it is very important indeed that we do what we can to remove the impost of taxes on production in this country. Broadly speaking of course, the move to a broad based, rebatable indirect tax system in this country in fact reduces taxes and charges on our export sector by some $4½ billion—that is, $4,500 million—a year. I believe that that is a very worthwhile objective for the Australian economy. In that sense, as we celebrate today the dawning of a very significant new set of opportunities for the broader economy, we do so for rural and regional economies as well. A large part of that taxation reform involves the measures that we are putting in place through the extension of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme and the introduction of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme 1999. A large part of the benefits that flow to rural and regional Australia do indeed derive from those two measures.

speech.para: There has been some speculation, I think it is fair to say, on compliance issues. It is not at all unusual for a government—in fact, it is the norm—to introduce an act which clearly sets out its objectives and clearly outlines where it intends to go with something like the diesel rebate scheme, which is quite straightforward in terms of compliance and so forth, but more particularly the alternative fuels grants scheme. It needs to be acknowledged and it is a reality that, as we have started serious negotiations in relation to administration and compliance, the difficulties are a little more than we had initially anticipated.

It also needs to be acknowledged that that is, in effect, Labor's fault. They could have chosen to have entered into meaningful negotiations with us. They chose not to. So we had to negotiate with the Democrats. I have said in this place, and I repeat, that we entered into negotiations with them and found them to be absolutely fair, reasonable and constructive. As noted in an editorial in a very important rural paper today, the fact of the matter is that the Daily Liberal from Dubbo in the electorate of the member for Parkes has observed:
The rebate is worth the small cost of extra paperwork. Not surprisingly the opposition is having a field day on certain aspects of the federal government's amended reform tax package.

It goes on to say that the benefits are going to be enormous and that this will be a very good package for rural and regional Australia and well worth the effort. I sincerely believe that to be the case. I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —I just remind the Minister for Transport and Regional Services that we did in fact vote for these bills once they were disentangled from the whole tax package. We voted for them. We have said to you that we do support reduced transport costs, but we do think that we could do it a little better. We think we could go about it in a more pro-active and positive way for government. We would like to put to you the challenge of achieving greater environmental benefits than you have so far.

speech.para: The problem for you is that you signed up for a deal without either of the parties having a single clue about how it would work. You had transport fuel goals—

talk.start.para: —I remind the member for Dickson that it is not a problem for the chair.

—Sorry, Mr Speaker. The minister on behalf of the government had some transport fuel goals. The Democrats had some alternative energy environmental goals. So we got this botched, hybrid solution. The minister and those who helped put the deal in place—and we saw this demonstrated in question time yesterday and today—do not seem to have a clue how it was going to work. We heard Senator Allison's first version. We had the mark I version which said, `Oh, well, it might be where the trucks go; it might be the kind; it might be the distance they travel.' When the minister was put on the spot over that, he said, `No, it won't be about that at all.'

speech.para: We are told that the compliance legislation is coming in the spring sitting. We are told that the definition of metropolitan boundaries is coming some time later by way of regulation. We are told that the details of the new alternative energy programs are coming some time later. We are told that the penalties for non-compliance are coming—again, some time later. I said in the second reading debate, and I say it again now: it is a bit rich to ask us to keep signing up to things when governments cannot tell us how the implementation will work. That is why we have asked so many questions. Even today the minister flick passed a fundamental question on the regional wine industry to the Treasurer. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services could not answer a question on regional industry.

We have not been able to have any satisfactory answers to the fundamental questions of capacity for rorting, to the fundamental questions of where you will place the arbitrary lines and what that will mean for businesses. We have not had any answers to the possible inequities in the competitive balance between businesses depending upon whether they are just inside or just outside the metropolitan area. The whole thing has been exposed as a huge problem for you in the same way as has compliance on what food is going to have the GST applied and what is not. Just as the food issue will come back to haunt the Treasurer, I think the compliance aspects of this diesel package—they may have some positive aspects—will come back to haunt the minister. It is fundamentally flawed. So far it has been demonstrated to be unworkable. Nothing the minister has said or, more correctly, has not said has changed or can alter that fact.
Amendment agreed to.

debate.para: Motion (by Mr Tuckey) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Information is the currency of humanity, and humanity is the catalyst for change. In the age of information, change is inevitable and the possible now becomes the probable. The use of information technology has brought much change, even to this place. I address the House tonight, speaking not from written notes or from memory but with my words and thoughts stored on a portable hand-held device, a PDA. In fact, I believe I may be the first member to do this.

speech.para: This PDA allows me to deliver a prepared speech that has never been set to paper. The paperless office may yet become a reality one day. I also store in this device all of my tasks, my complete diary and my phone book. It also has the ability to fax and access the World Wide Web. But, more importantly, this device synchronises completely with my electorate office. Technology such as this is having a huge impact on the way this House operates and the way that we govern in Australia. While such technologies continue to reduce demand on our use of physical resources, the real advantage of information technology is in the limitless interaction of people and ideas.

This parliament should not be constrained in the way that information technologies are used in the business of the House. This parliament is already one of the most, if not the most, technologically sophisticated legislatures in the world. From our parliamentary offices we have electronic connections that enable the transfer of data from one member to another or to our constituents and for the downloading of Hansard, press releases, Bills Digests, legislation and other documents and information from parliamentary sources.

This building is one of largest in the world to be built around an electronic backbone of fibre optics. Previous governments deserve congratulations for their commitment to new technology and the efficiency it can bring to the day-to-day operations of government. In fact, at least to some extent, the overwhelming enthusiasm of the Australian people towards new technologies stems from the enthusiasm shown by Australian governments to utilise technology.

However, just as the development of information technology has grown exponentially, so too government must commit resources and infrastructure at a faster pace. All of this has given elected representatives a greater ability to access information and services and greater access to our constituents and a greater ability to do more for our community. But current technology could allow us to achieve even more, as is often required.

Since the invention of the printing press, technological advancement has accelerated and broadened the spread of human knowledge, thoughts and beliefs. Current technologies give to billions the voice that once belonged only to the few, so we must listen to these many voices. The challenge for us now is our commitment to foster the enthusiasm of the community towards new technologies. While many government departments use the Internet as a primary resource for providing information to the community and the parliament and the parliamentary library conducts research through the Internet, there remains a frustrating delay in providing electorate offices with a permanent connection to these same resources.

Current technologies should also be employed to fully integrate the offices in our community with our offices here in Canberra. The single office concept needs to move beyond concept and into reality. The current system of operating two separate networks is totally inefficient. Through technology we can minimise the impact of our absence from our electorates. Anything that allows us to do more and better work in our community must be utilised. In the new age of telecommuting, e-commerce, and being on-line, Canberra to my electorate of Oxley need no longer be such a distance away.

As a nation we have always recognised the tyranny of distance, in particular the isolation of low population density. Today we have further conquered that distance. This is why rural Australia has always embraced new technology, as have our business community and education sectors. The challenge for us is to do the same in this House. With today's technology we can create the parliament of tomorrow. The need for mobile equipment and access should go beyond trial and also become a reality. The thought of conducting elections over the Internet may seem radical today, but our colleagues overseas are conducting such ventures as we speak and there are legislatures already using computerised voting to avoid time consuming counts during debates. I envisage the day when interactive terminals at our seats in the House will keep members and the Speaker up to date. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —May I be permitted to observe that when the electronic machine that the member for Oxley was using responds to voice activation we will have come full circle.

—This evening I would like to take a few minutes to share some thoughts on some of the most admirable people I have come across in my travels around the electorate. I am not referring to mayors or shire councillors; I am not referring to doctors or sporting geniuses or academic marvels. I am talking about two groups of people whom I have had the pleasure of meeting recently. They are the young people associated with the Green Corps program.

speech.para: I had the absolute honour some weeks ago to be involved in the presentation to the Green Corps group from Broken Hill, who had just finished their six months on a Green Corps project. I do not need to point out to those members in the House that the people who participate in the Green Corps project are volunteers. They are young people who have been on the dole who have decided that there is more to life for them and have decided, of their own volition, to join the Green Corps project.

Gerard Bennett, Matthew Chandler, Rachel Daley, Carl Krelle (otherwise known as Rainbow), Calvin Lee, Scott Nilson, Leah McWaters and Darren Thomas: these eight people—seven of them from my electorate and residents of Broken Hill and one from Rainbow in Victoria—were working during the six months leading up to about April. One of the tasks that was undertaken, under the supervision of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, was something that I would say many adult Australians who spend time berating the young people of today would not even consider doing. These young people, amongst other things, performed jobs such as installing Environet, creating signs for National Parks, revegetating areas, digging holes for fence posts, et cetera. But the thing that I marvelled at when I met these people was the job that they did without a word of complaint in the 40 degree plus heat of a Broken Hill summer in January, rolling up about 120 kilometres of barbed wire.

The dedication and commitment that these people showed to perform these tasks, after starting off a somewhat disparate group of people—some of whom knew each other, many who did not—were remarkable. They formed a team, they learned a lot about life, they learned a lot about relationships. They certainly learned a lot about hard work and, most importantly, they learned about the pleasure and the satisfaction gained from getting stuck into a job, whether it is hard or not, and seeing it through.

These young people had a great time in the Green Corps. It is probably not the type of work that many people would choose, but these young Australians were motivated and excited when they were finished. Many of them were going to take the opportunity to get hold of some further funds to continue with study. It will look terrific on their CVs—the fact that they have contributed to society in this way. They probably did not care whether or not I was there for their presentation, or the mayor or whoever else. The highlight at the end of their Green Corps time was to sit down and chat about the experience and what they had achieved for themselves.

It was a privilege and an honour for me to meet these people, and I hold them up as representatives to anyone who questions the work of Green Corps. More importantly, I hold them up as an example to anyone who gets on a soapbox and talks about the youth today in a disparaging way. These people face challenges that, as young people, we never had to face. They have risen above these challenges and met them and punched them in the eye.

I recently also had the pleasure of launching another Green Corps group who are just starting on their learning journey in Parkes—another fine, motivated group of people really looking forward to getting stuck into the work at hand. All of them are appreciative of the opportunity that they were given and I am sure that, like their Broken Hill counterparts, they will also benefit enormously and the community will benefit enormously in turn from their valuable input.

I look forward to finding out, at the completion of this Parkes Green Corps project, just how many of them finish and what their hopes and aspirations will be then. After what I have seen already, I will be most surprised if the number finishing are any fewer than the number that started.

talk.start.para: —I speak on behalf of at least 3,000 retirees who have invested at least $300 million, many of whom have lost their entire life savings in an out of control pooled investment scheme. I appeal to the federal Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman, to establish a team within Centrelink to set in place guidelines so that the devastated investors can access their legal entitlements without delay. At the moment the devastated investors, with no income and frozen assets, are trudging into Centrelink offices around the country and being told that they are ineligible for income assistance. As a consequence many are without any form of income even though many should be eligible for special benefit. It is not the fault of staff behind the counter in Centrelink, rather the failure of this government to appreciate the nature of the disaster and the predicament these individuals find themselves in. Currently two finance brokers, Global Finance and Grubb Finance, are in liquidation. Three more firms are in difficulty. In the Western Australian parliament, the Minister for Fair Trading, Mr Doug Shave, has confirmed that up to 5,000 investors may lose their money and up to $500 million may be involved.

speech.para: On Saturday 19 June I attended a meeting in Perth with approximately 100 of these investors who have been disgracefully let down by the regulatory framework nationally and in the state of Western Australia. There are many more right across Australia, includ ing many in my home state of Queensland. The Western Australian authorities are yet to appoint a supervisor to liquidate the trust funds, and in the meantime what remains of the investors' assets are frozen and the amount that remains is unknown. With their nest eggs frozen, many of these people are without any income. They are told by Centrelink that they have too much equity to receive temporary support from the federal government. It is my understanding that many of these people may be eligible for special benefit—a discretionary payment that can be paid to a person who meets certain conditions and is unable to provide a sufficient livelihood for themselves or their dependents. Income testing of special benefit is also discretionary and usually involves a deduction of $1 for each dollar of income.

With respect to the assets test, the Social Security Act provides that where a person's social security entitlement has been reduced under that test and the asset in question is unrealisable, and if the application of the test puts the person in severe financial hardship, the unrealisable asset can be disregarded under the ordinary income and assets test. However, where such an asset has been disregarded in this way, the pension rate will be reduced under a fairly complex formula that takes account of income from other sources, assets other than those that have been disregarded and the value of the disregarded assets themselves. As a matter of urgency, Senator Newman should establish a team to assess the overall situation and put in place guidelines for behind-the-counter staff in Centrelink to use when they are approached by these retirees, many of whom have been defrauded of their life savings.

The activities of those running these pooled investment schemes are not unlike the recent business failures—take, for example, the Oakdale colliery—that have left many workers short-changed. Just before Christmas 1998 the Austral Pacific bus plant at Geebung in the electorate of Lilley closed as a result of the failure of the Clifford group of companies. In total about 240 jobs were lost. According to the figures from the receiver, an amount exceeding $6.5 million was due to employees, and that is now unlikely to be returned to those employees. Employee entitlements included at least five months of employer funded superannuation instalments and three months of voluntary superannuation payments deducted from employees' wages. The last deficiency is particularly appalling. The directors of the failed company included John Barrie Loiterton and Ian Hall. These two directors were also the directors of Globane, which had a liquidator appointed in 1996—the same year in which Gilba Holdings failed. Loiterton was also involved in an early company failure in 1974 when Vanbro Corporation went to the wall. The receiver estimates that the total deficiency for the group will be in excess of $79 million. In January of this year I referred this matter to the government and I wait with interest the results of an ASIC inquiry into this gross business failure.

I simply cannot imagine just how I would react if I lost everything, especially if it were someone else's doing. For retirees whose life savings are now frozen, with no source of income, and the workers in my electorate who have lost their jobs and thousands in entitlements and superannuation, words would be of little comfort. What they desperately need is some action from this government, via all possible means to assist them in their time of hardship and to make sure they are not hung out to dry by the dodgy characters that have ripped them off.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to support comments made last week by Senator Nick Minchin, Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, regarding the serious situation we face in Western Australia with the continuing downturn in mineral exploration. According to ABS statistics, exploration expenditure in WA dropped by $15 million in the March quarter, down 11 per cent from December 1998. This is part of a continuing trend that is threatening the mining and resource sector as well as the overall economy in my state. Apart from employing more than 45,000 people, the mining sector in WA is responsible for 65 per cent of the state's total invest ment, which equates to 58 per cent of the total mining investment in Australia.

speech.para: The three main causes of the downturn in exploration expenditure identified by the WA Chamber of Minerals and Energy are lower commodity prices, access to venture capital and uncertainty created by native title legislation being blocked in the WA state parliament. There is little we can do other than ride out the storm of falling commodity prices and the current economic downturn being experienced around the world, but the state upper house in WA is in a position to help turn around the fall in mining exploration.

They can do this by allowing the Court government to proceed with the native title legislation that complements the Commonwealth's Native Title Act. Although the Titles Validation Amendment Bill was passed in April, albeit seven months after it was introduced, the Native Title (State Provisions) Bill is still to be passed by non-government members in the upper house.
Mr Melham interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is true, Daryl. It is time these members in the upper house realised just how important the mining sector is to the WA economy. While bearing in mind around 78 per cent of the state is currently the subject of native title claims, it is time they had a look around the state and noticed that vital exploration work is rapidly disappearing because of the uncertainty their actions have created. The only positive news is that mining companies, most likely out of frustration with the upper house, have signed a deal with the Kimberley Land Council to cover the issue of exploration across the north-west of WA. They are probably fed up with the delays caused by parliamentarians and want to get on with the job.

speech.para: Mining companies are also looking offshore for mineral exploration projects because of the problems they face here, which means Australia is missing out on important export dollars. I call on the upper house to take their responsibility to the people of Western Australia seriously and, for the sake of future generations of our wonderful state, end the uncertainty the mining industry is facing by passing the remainder of the native title legislation.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to talk about what I regard as a major failure of the GST package. In doing so, I refer to a conspicuous absence from negotiations, as pursued by the Democrats, of any focus at all on the question of jobs. If anything, I also suggest to the House this evening that there is no excuse for the Democrats totally ignoring the jobs issue. I also suggest that, to retain any credibility with the public, the Democrats had to ensure that the package would not cost jobs—in this endeavour the Democrats have failed dismally.

speech.para: At the last election, and confirmed again since the election, the Democrats made a number of non-negotiable commitments on how they would improve the employment impact of the package. The minimum jobs hurdle they set themselves called on the government to replace $2.5 billion of petrol and diesel tax cuts with cuts to payroll tax, address the job damaging effects of the tax mix, reduce the maximum taper rate on unemployment benefits, replace the proposed First Home Buyers Scheme with a GST rebate and zero rate inbound tourism packages.

Not one of these commitments has been fully satisfied. How then do the Democrats reconcile this with their understandable desire to be as far removed from a GST as possible, as they initially stated to the Australian public? Beyond their minimum benchmark on jobs, the Democrats also wanted the government to explain the issues that were not resolved to their satisfaction in the Senate committee process. I again suggest that, in doing their deal, they failed to fulfil that undertaking.

I raise these issues because I consider at the moment that we should have a major debate on the issue of jobs. I consider that the government actually failed Australia's young unemployed last Thursday afternoon in their hasty endeavour to bring before the parliament their youth employment bill going to the question of junior rates. I consider that we should step back, properly consider the Australian Industrial Relations Commission report and basically pursue a case by case approach on the basis of any applicant having to prove the merits of their case. This is exceptionally important in the light of the GST package—the consideration of which has today been completed—and the fact that, beyond the GST package which will in actual fact destroy jobs, we have a government that is, in essence, failing on the jobs front.

All we get from the government when it comes to a debate about jobs is an endeavour to shift blame and an endeavour to suggest that there is yet another excuse. Initially we had the question of junior rates. The question of junior rates can now be properly resolved with the assistance of the Australian Labor Party and, more importantly, with the help of a constructive report from the Industrial Relations Commission.

Also consider that, when you look at the plight of the long-term unemployed today, they are entitled to more than suggestions by the Minister for Employment Services that they are job snobs. They are entitled to more than mere suggestions by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, assisted by the Minister for Employment Services, that the solution to unemployment in this country is Work for the Dole.

I want to clearly state this evening that, from the Labor Party's point of view, we understand that in the Australian community there is a range of organisations, including local councils and community organisations and members of the Job Network, that desire to use Work for the Dole because, in essence, it is the only scheme available at the moment to offer any form of assistance at all to the unemployed. In indicating that I am not attacking those organisations, I also clearly indicate to the House this evening that I would hope that, in embracing Work for the Dole, those organisations actually endeavour to add to Work for the Dole by trying, from their own limited local resources, to ensure that a form of accredited training is given to the unemployed who are obligated to undertake Work for the Dole activity.

I raise the question of accredited training because I consider that, in any activity, we should be about giving the unemployed skills that are relevant to a job in the local community. That represents a fairly significant statement from the Australian Labor Party to the House this evening. We were the first to bring in the reciprocal obligation. We do not think Work for the Dole is adequate, but we understand it is the only existing scheme at the moment. All we ask is that those organisations who embrace it actually try to add to the endeavours of the government by incorporating into the scheme some decent training which actually rewards the unemployed for facing up to their responsibilities and, in doing so, assists them in endeavouring to get job ready and to be more attractive to employers in the Australian community. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Agents Regulation Authority: Migration Agents
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 571)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1999:

question.para: (1) During the Migration Agents Regulation Authority's (MARA) first three months of operation, (a) against which migration agents were complaints made, (b) what was the name of each agent whose registration was suspended and (c) what was the period of suspension in each case.
(2) What penalties can MARA apply to agents who breach MARA's code of conduct, other that suspension of registration.

(3) Is there a need to improve migration agents' conduct, especially because many agents are lodging applications which they know have no chance of success and which are designed to delay their clients being made to leave Australia; if so, does his Department record for each migration agent (a) how many applications did they lodge (b) their success rate and (c) the fees charged for the service they perform.
(4) Who will the Government consult, other than MARA, on ways to further improve migration agents' conduct.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —In my answer to part (1)(b) of the honourable member's question (Hansard , 13 May 1999, page 4459) incorrect information was provided. The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) It is not possible to provide to the honourable Member the names of agents against whom complaints were made. Unless the name of an agent has been published because of a decision by the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA) to cancel of suspend the agent's registration, the names of agents who are subject to complaints are not made publicly available. To do so may prejudice the agent, especially where the complaint has been resolved in the agent's favour or has not been resolved.
(b) One agent, Mr Jun Yuan, had his registration suspended in the period.
(c) The period of suspension was for six months.

(2) Under section 303 of the Migration Act 1958, MARA may cancel the agent's registration by removing his or her name from the Register of Migration Agents, or caution the agent. When an agent has been cautioned, that fact is included on the Register for the period of the caution.
(3) Yes. MARA was established to undertake this function and has taken firm action to discipline agents who have been involved in unethical conduct.

Regarding visa applications with "no chance of success", my Department in consultation with the Migration Institute of Australia is examining ways of further strengthening the Code of Conduct to address this matter.
(a) The Departmental data base records whether a visa applicant has been assisted by a migration agent.
(b) The Department does not collect information relating to the number of applications lodged by a particular agent or on the success rate.
(c) Agents are not required to inform the Department about fees charged for services.
(4) The Government will consider constructive proposals from any source to improve migration agents' conduct.
The Code of Conduct will be examined by the review of statutory self-regulation which is being conducted by officers of my Department and guided by a Reference Group of independent experts.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force Base, Williamtown: Noise Levels
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 633)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Does his Department acknowledge that unacceptable noise levels affect a number of residential properties on Nelson Bay Road, Williamtown, NSW, in direct line with the flight path of the runway at RAAF Williamtown.
(2) Will he (a) authorise a survey of the area to determine how many properties are affected and (b) consider the acquisition of properties identified by the survey as adversely affected.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australian Noise Exposure Forecast (ANEF) techniques were developed in 1982 and forecasts of the area adjacent to RAAF Williamtown have been produced. The forecasts indicate that some properties in Nelson Bay Road, in direct alignment with the flight path, experience high noise levels.

(2) (a) The last endorsed ANEF for RAAF Williamtown was produced in 1992 and forecasts the level of noise exposure until 2002. Defence is developing a new model incorporating the Hawk Lead In Fighter aircraft which will replace the Macchi aircraft currently operating from RAAF Williamtown. The forecast will indicate those properties subjected to high noise levels and local authorities will need to implement appropriate land management planning for the relevant areas surrounding the airfield.

(b) Defence property acquisition is generally only undertaken in support of endorsed operational or training requirements. The Department does not acquire noise-affected property unless there are exceptional circumstances.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Defence Land Acquisition: Compensation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 634)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Will his Department pay `solatium' to all residents of Slades Road, Williamtown, NSW, whose homes have been compulsorily acquired by his Department because of excessive noise levels.
(2) Does his Department accept that the quality of life of the residents, who are mostly aged, has been diminished by the forced acquisition and subsequent relocation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The properties in Slades Road have not been compulsorily acquired. The acquisition program is voluntary which is subject to the requirements of the Lands Acquisition Act 1989. Notwithstanding the voluntary nature of these acquisitions, the Act ensures that the property owners are treated equitably and fairly in dealing with the Commonwealth.

(2) Fourteen properties have been acquired on a voluntary basis and agreement has been reached with a further four owners. Negotiations are continuing on three properties and owners of three other properties have indicated they do not wish to sell.

The Department engaged the Australian Valuation Office to value each property that was identified by owners as potentially for sale. Each property was assessed on the basis of its worth, ignoring the fact that it adjoined the airfield. The Department also agreed to pay:
(a) costs for a second private valuation appointed by the vendor,
(b) the vendors legal costs associated with the sale and the purchase of another property of a similar value,
(c) stamp duty charges associated with the purchase of a property of similar value,
(d) removal costs, and
(e) payment of incidental costs such as telephone reconnection fees.

Defence indicated from the outset that it would not pay solatium. If the properties were valued and purchased at their true value, that is, `as is, where is', then a solatium payment may have been appropriate. Given the circumstances of these properties, the Commonwealth determined that the best approach for the owners was to purchase their properties as outlined above.

(2) No. This was a voluntary program and nobody has been forced to relocate. The approach taken by the Commonwealth has provided the opportunity for residents to move away from the airfield and receive fair recompense for their properties, including relocation costs, that might not otherwise have been achievable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that (a) a heritage study is being conducted on the Stockton Rifle Range and (b) agents have been commissioned to dispose of assets at the site before the heritage study has been completed; if so, will he ensure that (i) the appointment of agents to dispose of assets is terminated and no disposals occur until the results of the study have been fully and fairly considered and (ii) the site will be preserved in its entirety if the study finds that the site and its appointments have heritage significance.

(2) Did the Government undertake before the 1998 general election to give the site to a trust and have it returned to its former use as an active rifle range; if so, will he ensure that the undertaking is delivered.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes, a heritage assessment of the Stockton Rifle Range property has been carried out and a draft report received by Defence.

(b) An agent has been commissioned to sell the caretaker's residence that has been assessed as being of low heritage significance in the draft report and could be removed from the site. This action was taken as there is a risk of vandalism to the residence.

(i) It is intended to retain the agent until the residence is sold or it is concluded that there is no market interest. There is no intention to dispose of any other assets before the final report of the heritage assessment is completed.
(ii) The draft report of the heritage assessment indicates that only a limited number of features and improvements on the property are of any heritage significance, rather than the entire site.

(2) The Federal Government did not make any commitment in regard to the retention of the Stockton Rifle Range and there is no intention of gifting the site. The property is surplus to Defence requirements and disposal action is under way.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Opera House: World Heritage Listing
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 644)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 June 1999:

question.para: (1) On what dates since his answer to question No. 2409 (Hansard, 14 May 1998, page 3500) has he written to the Premier of New South Wales or has the Premier written to him concerning the nomination of the Sydney Opera House for inscription on the World Heritage List.
(2) Will the nomination be lodged in time to be considered at the next session of the World Heritage Bureau.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Premier of New South Wales, the Hon Bob Carr MP, wrote to the Prime Minister concerning nomination of the Sydney Opera House for inscription on the World Heritage List on 3 May 1999. The Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of New South Wales on the same topic on 8 June 1999.

(2) No. The next meeting of the World Heritage Bureau is scheduled for 5-10 July 1999. Under the Operational Guidelines for the World Heritage Convention, a nomination submitted by 1 July in one year would be considered at the Bureau meeting in June/July of the following year.
